quickStart.title: Your First 7 Days
quickStart.subtitle: A gentle start to your 12-Month Money Reset
quickStart.intro: Feeling nervous or overwhelmed? That's completely normal. This planner is designed for real life — no perfection required. Follow these simple steps in your first week.
quickStart.day1Desc: Fill out the Financial Starting Point page with your income, fixed expenses, and current savings/debt. This is your baseline — no judgment, just information.
quickStart.day2Desc: Choose 1–3 goals that really matter to you. Write WHY each goal is important — this will keep you motivated when things get hard.
quickStart.day3Desc: Read the Debt Payoff mini guide. Pick Snowball (smallest first) or Avalanche (highest interest first). Circle your choice.
quickStart.day4Desc: Use the 50/30/20 guide as a starting point. Fill in the "Planned" column for January. Don't overthink it — you can adjust later.
quickStart.day5Desc: Pick ONE day and time each week (Sunday evening works great). Add a recurring reminder to your phone. This is non-negotiable.
quickStart.day6Desc: Go to the Subscriptions page and list everything you pay for monthly/yearly. Cancel or downgrade what you don't really use.
quickStart.day7Input: In {{year}}, I want my money to help me...
quickStart.rememberText: You don't have to do all of this perfectly. If you miss a day, just pick up where you left off. The goal isn't perfection — it's progress. You're already ahead of most people just by starting.

howToUse.title: How to Use This Planner
howToUse.subtitle: Your roadmap for the year ahead
howToUse.step1Desc: Begin with your Financial Starting Point to understand where you are right now.
howToUse.step2Desc: Define 1-3 meaningful financial goals for the year.
howToUse.step3Desc: Fill out your monthly budget at the start of each month. Review and adjust weekly.
howToUse.step4Desc: Use the expense tracker to log spending. 5 minutes a day is all you need.
howToUse.step5Desc: At month's end, complete the reflection section. Learn and improve.
howToUse.weeklyRoutineDesc: Pick one day each week (15-20 minutes):
howToUse.tipText: Don't try to be perfect. The best budget is one you'll actually use. Start simple and adjust as you learn what works for you.

budgetGuide.title: The 50/30/20 Budget Guide
budgetGuide.subtitle: A simple framework for your money
budgetGuide.flexibleText: The 50/30/20 rule is a starting point, not a rigid rule. If you're paying off debt aggressively, you might do 50/20/30. If you live in an expensive city, needs might be 60%. Adjust to fit YOUR life.

debtGuide.title: Debt Payoff Strategies
debtGuide.subtitle: Choose your path to freedom
snowballSteps: List debts from smallest to largest balance
Put extra money toward the smallest debt
When it's paid off, roll that payment to the next smallest
debtGuide.snowballBest: Best for: People who need quick wins to stay motivated
debtGuide.avalancheDesc: Pay off highest interest rate first
avalancheSteps: List debts from highest to lowest interest rate
Put extra money toward the highest interest debt
When it's paid off, roll that payment to the next highest interest
debtGuide.avalancheBest: Best for: People who want to save the most money on interest
debtGuide.truthText: The best method is the one you'll stick with. Both work. Pick one and start.
